    • Trends in American Baby Names

    Trends in American Baby Names

    trends.Rmd

    Introduction

    This vignette explores long-term patterns in American baby names using the dataset included in the mycommonnames package.

    Data overview 

    library(mycommonnames)
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union
glimpse(names)
#> Rows: 1,924,665
#> Columns: 5
#> $ year       <dbl> 1880, 1880, 1880, 1880, 1880, 1880, 1880, 1880, 1880, 1880,…
#> $ sex        <chr> "F", "F", "F", "F", "F", "F", "F", "F", "F", "F", "F", "F",…
#> $ name       <chr> "Mary", "Anna", "Emma", "Elizabeth", "Minnie", "Margaret", …
#> $ count      <int> 7065, 2604, 2003, 1939, 1746, 1578, 1472, 1414, 1320, 1288,…
#> $ proportion <dbl> 0.07238359, 0.02667896, 0.02052149, 0.01986579, 0.01788843,…

    Example: name trends 

    names |>
filter(name %in% c("Samantha", "Scarlette"), sex == "F") |>
ggplot(aes(year, count, color = name)) +
geom_line(linewidth = 1.2) +
labs(x = "Year", y = "Number of babies", color = "Name") +
theme_minimal()

    Summary

    The mycommonnames dataset and Shiny app let users explore how naming popularity evolves over time. For example, Samantha dominated in the 90s, while Scarlette rose early 20s.

    Developed by Sumintra Boonmat.
